faster than seems at all

the lifestyles are not really that

different kinds of nights and different

let's take this a bit more seriously
I think that what most of us have in

about rock stars is that other
well-known meme the 10x programmer
someone that can create better code
faster than other people and who can

Die Young and leave a lot of collateral

Rockstar programmers is that they are

by finishing more features than other

this is all very nice if true but it
often isn't and it's often inches away
from some really quite nasty messes I
have worked on teams with people like
that and it's great in the right context
I've also worked on the teams where
people sort out the drama and even once

look like Heroes I've seen people who
saw themselves as rock stars and cut
Corners to make the release so that
they'd look good but as a result they

from obviously this is not good this is
the programmer equivalent of throwing
the TV into the swimming pool at the

that I have with the idea of Rockstar
programmers I think that it's a terrible
idea to plant as an aspiration into
people's heads none of the people that
I've ever worked with or met that I
think of as great sometimes worldclass
program
think of themselves as rock stars most
of them certainly knew that they were
good but that's not the same thing at
all none of the people that I have met
that appear to think of themselves as
rock stars have been any good as far as
I've been able to
tell yet these are the people that the
lazy recruiters and employers want to
find I've been lucky to work with a few
people that were genuinely great in my
opinion at the top end of the bell curve
and I've seen others that may have been
smarter or at least they certainly
thought they were but weren't as much
value to the team or ultimately to the

about how smart we are though that plays
a role it's also matters how people work
and how they add value to the team and
that leads to the second objection and
probably if I'm honest my main one that
I have with the idea of the Rockstar
programmer professional software
development is mostly a team sport you
can certainly have Rockstar teams maybe
they're rock bands but the great teams
are greater than the sum of their parts
it's not about individual performance
it's about how it all comes together in
the end I have in mind here some
personal experience I worked on a
worldclass team that's not me saying
that others said that about the team it
was widely Rec they were widely
recognized for their excellence
the team was fantastic but it wasn't
packed full of geniuses we were all very
good but I thought of us as a bunch of
very good developers with world-class
habits rather than programming rock
stars at a different time in my career I
worked in a different organization I
think that if I am honest the average
Talent whatever that may mean the raw
smartness perhaps of the people on this
other team may have been higher they did
very good work but it was less
Innovative developed more slowly and had
more bugs they weren't in the same
league as the first team so there are
two well at least two Dimensions to this
there is the talent of the individuals
and the quality of their approach to the
work the first team in my example were a
worldclass team because of the
combination of the people and their
approach the second was a team of very
talented individuals but working in ways
that limited the impact of their
talents this isn't an easy relationship
to unpick the problem is that at the
extremes great people can make almost
any situation work mainly because if the
approach gets in the way they'll subvert
it in order to make progress but
ultimately a good person will always be
stopped by a bad process if it's bad
enough I was once working with a client

Developers at some point I said we can
generalize this and make the code a lot

winced and said uh okay but was
obviously reluctant to add the class I
assumed that he didn't like the design
that I was suggesting which is exactly
the kind of conversation that you want
to have with your pair so I asked him to

including adding references to the class
in some random yamamo files and even
filling in a form so that the class
could be added to their Version Control
System don't even ask me I have no idea
how they ended up in this position this
chap probably wasn't a rockar but he was
a very good programmer capable um who
was actively prevented from making
design choices that would make his life
and the code better at the other end of
the performance Spectrum poor performers
will struggle to make prog progess
perhaps whatever the process the usual
approach to solving this problem is to
micromanage the work of the poor
performers often this is
institutionalized into the requirements
process and the commit process
developers being told in specific detail
the design of the solution to implement
something that I call programming by
remote control and then being prevented
from committing changes until approved
by a more senior
colleague both of these are a failure of
trust maybe Justified maybe not but
either way you don't really fix these
kinds of trust Problems by being more
bureaucratic you fix them by making the
people you don't trust more
trustworthy this gets back once again to
how people work and the culture that
they work in now all this talk of bell
curves and topend performers and low-end

Draconian but I'm just trying to be
honest Hest and I have seen both that
there is a range of
capability I confess I perceive a
tension here between two ideas both of
which to some degree I subscribe to but
that ultimately are in
Conflict on the one hand the people
involved make a difference some people
are able to make be better progress than
others they can find the simple in
complex problems and even find ways to
eliminate the complexity sometimes on
the other hand I believe that the
biggest barrier to progress isn't that
people lack skill or are lazy or don't
know what they're doing it's that they
work in ways that stop them exercising
their skill that prevents them from
working efficiently and hides the
context of their work from them so it's
hard for them to understand what why
they're doing what they're doing this is
the stuff that stops great people making
progress so it gets in the way for the
rest of us two despite sitting on the
fence what I am sure of is that the unit
of Effectiveness in professional
software development is the team not the
individual so we want good people but
even more than that we want good teams a
few years ago Google did some research
it was called project Aristotle they
wanted to understand what made a great
team I'm pretty sure that they started
out assuming that they would find an
ideal mix
of Highly talented types of people
necessary to build great teams that's
how most organizations think of this
kind of problem and the roots of the
Rockstar idea really but what they
actually found was a repeat of research
done 40 years earlier by Meredith belbin
belbin did Research into teams too also
looking for what made great teams he
found that if you make a team only of
rock stars you end up what with what he
called an Apollo team who end up
spending a lot of time engaged in
abortive debate in Belbin's words the
lack of coherent teamwork nullified the
gains of individual effort or
Brilliance so teams made up only of
rockars dissipate their advantage of
their
smartness High performing teams in the
belbin model were made up of a mix of
different types of people all of them
important belbin came up with a model of
nine roles that are necessary for
Effective teams I'm not going to explore
these in detail but here are a couple of
examples just so you can understand what
I'm talking about a teamworker helps the
team to gel using their versatility to
identify the work required and complete
it on behalf of the team their strengths
are that they're Cooperative perceptive
and diplomatic they listen and avert
friction their allowable weaknesses are
that they could be indecisive in crunch
situations and tend to avoid
confrontation don't be surprised to find
that they might be a little hesitant to
make unpopular decisions now compare
that to another of Belbin's role types
the plant who tends to be highly
creative good at solving problems in
unconventional ways their strengths are
creative imaginative free thinking
generates ideas and solve difficult
problems their allowable weaknesses are
that they might ignore incidentals and
maybe too preoccupied to really
communicate effectively don't be
surprised to find that they could also
be a bit absent minded or
forgetful people are usually a
combination of these nine different
roles to different
degrees I'm pretty strongly a plant and
not great as a completer finisher for
example a quick sidebar this isn't about
recognizing your weaknesses and working
to strengthen them rather the reverse
it's about recognizing your strengths
and maximizing them and working with
other people who can cover your
weaknesses while you cover theirs this
is what great teams do so a great team
has a good mix of all of these roles
represented Google spent two years
studying 180 teams um and their findings
mirrored bbins in many ways but they
also found some other interesting things
too they are identified five traits in
teams that indicated high performance
dependability work is done on time and
to a high standard structure and Clarity
the team and each member of it
understand their role and how it fits
into the bigger picture people
understand what they need to do and why
they're doing it meaning team members
work is important to them um Gallup
found that employees uh who use their

likely to be engaged in their work
playing to our strengths allows us to
take ownership of our work impact team
members believe that what they're
working on matters in a broader context
of some kind and last psychological
safety the degree to which team members
trust each other and are prepared to
take risks are you happy to point out
that the boss's ideas wrong or suggests
trying something radical just to see if
it works
these things require trust that your
ideas won't be dismissed or you
blamed and according to google
psychological safety is one of the key
predictors of great team performance the
researchers at Google wrote this who's
on the team matters less than how the
team members interact structure their
work and view their
contributions one final example of the
impact that culture and approach
have is one of my favorite stories from
Netflix at the height of their early
